36.59.text:

In fact I was in Geneva as a un fellow in

And for those following closely the most recent

203.10.text:

The great author and Nobel laureate Toni Morrison

213.65.text:
was once asked in an interview by Charlie
Rose about a question that Bill Moyers had

221.86.text:

white people?

228.52.text:
And it was a question that she cringed at

235.98.text:
Charlie Rose revisited this inquiry partly

245.17.text:

He suggested that perhaps she was importing

252.77.text:

Morrison rehearsed a few responses to the

260.55.text:

incidental question, but actually meant: when

269.64.text:
are you going to stop talking about race?
And Toni Morrison really nailed it for me

276.23.text:
when she spoke to the importance of text,
to the power of words, and to the power of

285.70.text:

And she said something along the lines of,

289.95.text:
'when you are black, and when you are reading,
you can feel the address of the narrator over

299.39.text:
my shoulder talking to someone else, talking
to somebody who is white, and you know that

308.71.text:
you are not the implied reader'.
Morrison delighted in her memory in the interview,

316.78.text:
of discovering black writers like Chinua Achebe
because for those texts, you, as a black person

325.44.text:
are the implied reader.
There is a language, a posture, a parameter

333.10.text:
that I or you as a black person could step
into and not be concerned, as she said, by

341.82.text:
'the white gaze'.
And that, she said, for her, was a liberating

354.72.text:
And when I heard that, I felt, well, one,

362.96.text:
as an Aboriginal person reading western literature.

371.91.text:

377.97.text:
I found myself quite out of depth in this

385.83.text:

392.87.text:

And in Michael Kirby I suppose I found someone

404.78.text:
judicially or extra-curailly, was not talking

413.03.text:
to me.
And I suppose that is why he is celebrated

417.31.text:

and for me for an Aboriginal kid, from Eagleby

425.64.text:
(I'm not sure where you found that information

430.50.text:

Here was a judge, he was someone who was talking

438.53.text:
to me.
And so when Bea invited me, Bea behind the

And in some ways the notion of the implied

the exigency of constitutional recognition

472.33.text:
So in tonight's lecture I wanted to do two
things.

478.72.text:
First I wanted to share with you a story of
one community that the Prime Minister's Expert

483.30.text:
Panel on the recognition of Aboriginal and
Torres Strait Islander peoples in the constitution

489.20.text:
visited, and that was the community of Cherbourg.
And then second I wanted to explain to you

496.81.text:
the process and the recommendations of the
panel; in particular the rational non-discrimination

504.08.text:
clause that we advocated for, that was very
much informed and enlivened by our visits

512.20.text:
to communities like Cherbourg.
My great grandmother Lily was an Aboriginal

519.59.text:
woman from Warra in southwest Queensland,
half-way between Dolby and Chinchilla.

525.66.text:
It's actually very close to Jimba station
where there was a well-known massacre of Aboriginal

532.02.text:
people.
And Lily had many, many, children including

536.21.text:
Fred my grandfather and Harry's brother, who
were all removed to Cherbourg from Warra during

543.71.text:
the protection era.
So Cherbourg, or Barambah, is an Aboriginal

549.90.text:
community in southeast Queensland that was
originally established by Salvation Army member

557.54.text:
William Thompson in 1899, and taken over as
a government settlement in 1904 under the

566.08.text:
Aboriginal Protection Act.
And it's well-known that tribes from all over

571.86.text:
Queensland and NSW were moved here.
My grandfather Fred, an initiated man who

578.74.text:
spoke many Aboriginal languages, grew up in
Cherbourg and worked throughout Queensland

584.11.text:
as a stockman, a cane cutter and a timber
cutter.

589.09.text:
And him and his brother Harry settled in Harvey
Bay where I grew up, where they bought land

595.30.text:
and married two South Sea Island sisters,
the Ober sisters, who were descendants of

603.62.text:
the black birding trade from Vanuatu.
The trade enforced an indentured labour that

611.40.text:
this year Australia celebrated the 150th anniversary
of the arrival of the first ship in Queensland

621.63.text:
on August the 14th 1863.
Although living on their land in Harvey Bay

628.94.text:
there was still a lot of family left behind
in Cherbourg, and I have cousins and aunties

635.58.text:
who remember my grandfather sending or sneaking
fresh fruit and seafood and blankets up to

641.48.text:
Cherbourg by rail.
Indeed many Aboriginal and South Sea Islander

647.17.text:
mob worked for Queensland rail including,
eventually, my own father for 45 years.

655.93.text:
And so it was in 2011 when I was appointed
by the Prime Minister to this expert panel,

664.45.text:
that we visited Cherbourg for a community
consultation.

670.33.text:
Cherbourg today stands proud as a community
at which the centre of stands the ration shed

678.90.text:
in the town's cultural precinct which also
includes the old superintendent's office and

686.08.text:
the old boys' dormitory.
It was from the ration shed that those on

691.39.text:
the settlement received rations, primarily
flour, sugar and meat, and at times rice,

699.02.text:
oatmeal and sago, in exchange for work within
the settlement.

706.96.text:
The ration shed stands as an icon of control
and oppression during the protection era in

712.55.text:
Australia.
An era that the history books tell us, was

719.70.text:
on one hand a welcome and distinct departure
from the brutal violence of the frontier and

727.13.text:
was aimed at doing something for the fast
disappearing races.

733.75.text:
And then on the other hand history books tell
us that is was to prevent the contamination

739.64.text:
of white blood and to exploit Aboriginal labour.
In 1968 Aboriginal people started to gain

749.82.text:
more freedom and rations ended in Cherbourg
and for decades the ration shed lay abandoned

756.91.text:
and decaying.
Until during preparations for the celebration

762.39.text:
of Cherbourg centenary in 2004, Sandra Morgan
and her sister Leslie Williams were collecting

770.19.text:
items for an historic display when they discovered
that the old ration shed at the bottom of

777.58.text:
the footy oval still lay intact
And they decided that the building should

785.01.text:
be preserved and relocated back to the centre
of the settlement and adapted as a museum.

791.98.text:
And so this community in the southeast of
Queensland reclaimed this abandoned ration

799.34.text:
shed that represented, the humiliation, the
deference, the lack of dignity of the protection

808.32.text:
era, and they transformed it into a powerful
symbol that is at the centrepiece of their

815.62.text:
proud tidy town.
And when the Expert Panel visited Cherbourg

821.57.text:
to conduct consultations on options for recognition
in the constitution, the community hosted

828.79.text:
us on the veranda of the ration shed, this
monument to survival, a defiant statement

836.68.text:
of resistance and a story of redemption.
In A dumping ground: A history of the Cherbourg

848.07.text:
settlement, Queensland historian Tom Blake
wrote in the opening paragraph:

854.49.text:
In the opening months of 1901 as white Australians
were undergoing their rite of passage into

859.89.text:
nationhood, another group of Australians were
also participating in a rite of passage, but

866.58.text:
a different kind.
In the Burnett district of southeast Queensland

871.88.text:
remnants of the Waka Waka tribe were being
rounded up and dumped on a reserve on the

877.39.text:
banks of Rumba Creek.
From camps on the fringes of towns and station

883.63.text:
properties they had been forced onto an Aboriginal
settlement established ostensibly for their

892.16.text:
care and protection.
For the Waka Waka, their rite of passage was

898.02.text:
not into nationhood or independence, but into
institutionalisation and domination.

908.79.text:
The two rituals were diametrically opposed,
the two rituals were diametrically opposed,

920.32.text:
and in many ways Cherbourg does exemplify
these two opposing rituals, the constitution

929.42.text:
and Aboriginal history.
How do you marry them in a way that does not

936.34.text:
offend what is an impermissible hindsight
when it comes to race relations and frontier

944.78.text:
violence in Australia?
The symbolism of us standing in the sun on

951.32.text:
the veranda of the ration shed holding boxes
of mini handbag-sized constitutions was not

960.54.text:
lost on us.
And I think that that is a good way to introduce

967.35.text:
the work of the Expert Panel and this contemporary
project for constitutional recognition of

975.13.text:
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.
We know for a fact, the implied reader of

982.46.text:
the constitution, of the very foundation of
the Australian state, was not Aboriginal and

988.92.text:
Torres Strait Islander peoples.
Now having said that, given the low level

994.82.text:
of civics' knowledge and understanding about
the constitution of Australia, an equally

1001.75.text:
plausible argument can be made that, but for
section 128, the Australian people were not

1009.07.text:
so much the implied reader of the constitution
either, as were the states and the federal

1016.28.text:
parliament.
Even Andrew Inglis Clark's due process clause

1022.00.text:
was transformed from an Australian's citizen
equal rights clause to an equal right clause

1029.52.text:
for trade between the states.
In any event the task of the expert panel

1038.02.text:
in 2011 was how to nudge the nation in a direction,
that you move them enough, to countenance

1047.51.text:
a change to a document that is so notoriously
rigid, so unchanging, so unremarkable, so

1057.34.text:
functional that, unlike many nations of the
world, so few of my Australian brothers and

1064.55.text:
sisters know that it even exists.
And in saying that, it does not mean that

1071.81.text:
this constitutional recognition project requires
us to traverse the politics of race in Australia

1080.93.text:
and pursue a soft agenda as exemplified by
the state parliaments' approach to recognition,

1089.44.text:
with a non-legal affect clause that is arguably
a type of non-recognition when accounting

1097.01.text:
for a non-legal effect clause, which really
defines the trend in state parliaments and

1103.09.text:
is utterly unnecessary in an ordinary act
of parliament.

1109.29.text:
But I think what the consensus report of the
Expert Panel tried to do in its delicately

1115.42.text:
poised treatment of Australian history and
recommendations for constitutional alteration,

1122.61.text:
what the recognised campaign is admirably
and skilfully trying to do now, and what we

1128.82.text:
as a nation must try to do in this project,
is to marry the two rituals in a way that

1135.06.text:
the implied reader is all Australians, that
it will speak to us all.

1141.68.text:
So what is the expert panel and what did it
do?

1145.06.text:
In 2010 there was a hung parliament, and in
negotiating for power the Greens and the Independent

1153.68.text:
Rob Oakeshott asked Prime Minister Gillard
to move, well not Prime Minister at the time,

1160.33.text:
but asked Julia Gillard to move upon the long-held
multi party support for constitutional recognition

1168.36.text:
of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
And so it was that Prime Minister Gillard

1174.36.text:
issued a terms of reference in very late December
2010 and constituted a panel to report to

1183.02.text:
the government within a year on possible options
for constitutional change.

1189.51.text:
Without going into too much detail on the
terms of reference, it required the Expert

1195.59.text:
Panel to lead a broad national consultation
and community engagement program to seek the

1202.84.text:
views of a wide spectrum of the community,
including those who live in rural and regional

1209.17.text:
areas.
It also required the Expert Panel to work

1213.49.text:
closely with organisations such as the Australian
Human Rights Commission, the National Congress

1219.94.text:
of Australia's First Peoples, and Reconciliation
Australia.

1226.01.text:
And in performing this role the Expert Panel
was to have regard to key issues raised in

1231.96.text:
the community in relation to Indigenous constitutional
recognition, the form of constitutional change,

1241.75.text:
approaches to a referendum that were more
likely to obtain widespread support from political

1247.75.text:
parties and the broader community, and the
implications of any proposed changes to the

1255.47.text:
constitution, including advice from constitutional
law experts.

1261.43.text:
The panel had 18 members with 6 ex offico
members and I won't name them all but they

1268.43.text:
included: Fred Chaney, Mark Liebler, Henry
Burmester QC, Graham Bradley, Glen Ferguson,

1277.52.text:
Noel Pearson, Patrick Dodson and Marcia Langton,
as well as representatives from all the political

1284.24.text:
parties including senator Rachel Siewert,
Independent Rob Oakeshott, and Ken Wyatt.

1293.28.text:
The Expert Panel agreed on four principles
to guide its assessment of the proposals for

1299.02.text:
constitutional alteration, and they were that,
each proposal must:

1306.28.text:
One, contribute to a more unified and reconciled
nation.

1310.99.text:
Two, to be of benefit and to accord with the
wishes of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander

1318.15.text:
peoples.
Three, to be capable of being supported by

1323.32.text:
an overwhelming majority of Australians from
across the political and social spectrums,

1330.76.text:
and fourth, to be technically and legally
sound.

1335.82.text:
We conducted a public consultation process
that involved the issuing of a discussion

1341.21.text:
paper on the options for constitutional recognition
and a public submissions process to go along

1347.29.text:
with that.
We held five months of public meetings and

1351.68.text:
events around Australia, and we also did polling
and focus groups including consultations with

1359.32.text:
constitutional lawyers and Aboriginal and
Torres Strait Islander leaders on the draft

1365.67.text:
final recommendations.
So the recommendations of the Expert Panel

1371.92.text:
were very much based upon the public submissions
and the views of the public including at public

1379.51.text:
meetings and events.
In addition, in terms of the work that we

1386.12.text:
did we were very much conscious of the fact
that we were building upon a foundation that

1391.50.text:
had already been laid down over three decades
in Australia.

1395.67.text:
There are many, many reports and recommendations
for reform of the constitution in regard to

1403.51.text:
indigenous peoples both substantively and
symbolically.

1409.22.text:
And that includes a 1983 senate standing - a
committee on constitutional and legal affairs,

1416.05.text:
a 1988 Constitutional Commission, the social
justice package arising out of the Mabo decision,

1424.31.text:
the 1998 Constitutional Convention, the Council
for Aboriginal Reconciliation in 2000, a 2003

1434.80.text:
Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee,
the 2008 Australia 2020 Summit, and a 2008

1444.50.text:
House of Representatives Standing Committee
on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

1450.72.text:
What I am emphasising here is that the advocacy
for recognition and reform, whether it be

1457.27.text:
the race power or an agreement-making power
or a symbolic preambular statement of recognition,

1464.83.text:
this has not been an Indigenous-only project.
It is one that has been shared along the way

1473.35.text:
by Indigenous and non-indigenous, progressive
and conservative alike.

1480.86.text:
So the culmination of all this work was a
comprehensive report to the Prime Minister

1485.24.text:
in January 2012 that reflected the length
and breadth of conversations that had occurred

1494.20.text:
in the Australian community about this issue.
And that included a chapter devoted to an

1500.46.text:
explanation of why race is a biologically
and scientifically defunct term, that it's

1507.22.text:
socially constructed and imprecise, and arbitrarily
and incapable of definition and scientific

1515.56.text:
demonstration.
The panel also felt that although the concept

1521.97.text:
of race is incapable of scientific definition
or demonstration, in Australia as elsewhere,

1529.32.text:
it persists as a powerful and persistent focus
of social identity and exclusion, and remains

1538.93.text:
a constitutionally available ground for legislation.
In addition to this, prominent among all Aboriginal

1550.91.text:
and Torres Strait Islander communities was
the question of sovereignty: Would recognition

1559.43.text:
foreclose on the question of sovereignty,
and the possibility of an agreement-making

1565.73.text:
power or a treaty?
So the panel included two chapters on sovereignty

1573.95.text:
and agreement making or treaty, to reflect
faithfully those very real and legitimate

1582.12.text:
concerns but did not make any recommendations
to those based on the methodology that we

1592.56.text:
adopted at the outset of the panel that militated
against any options unlikely to get broad

1602.93.text:
political and community support.
So what were the recommendations of the panel?

1612.94.text:
Recommendation one was that section 25 of
the constitution be repealed.

1619.66.text:
Section 25 is a provision which contemplates
the possibility of state laws disqualifying

1626.46.text:
people of a particular race from voting at
state elections.

1631.43.text:
Now it's a little bit more complicated than
that but the bottom line of section 25 is

1639.04.text:
that there is a multiparty support for the
deletion of section 25, there's no controversy

1646.78.text:
about its deletion and there is universal
agreement among commentators that it should

1653.09.text:
be deleted.
Recommendation two was that section 5126 of

1661.30.text:
the Australian constitution should be repealed.
So section 5126 is commonly refer to as the

1670.51.text:
race power.
Many of you would recall that in 1967 there

1676.68.text:
was a referendum, a successful referendum
in which this section was amended to remove

1682.51.text:
the words 'other than the Aboriginal people
in any state'.

1688.70.text:
Until this point the federal parliament did
not have the power to make laws for Aboriginal

1694.54.text:
people in states.
The removal of the words 'other than the Aboriginal

1700.19.text:
people in any state' conferred upon the federal
parliament the power to make laws in this

1706.82.text:
area, that the parliament shall have the power
to make laws with respect to the people of

1713.37.text:
any race.
And since 1967 the Commonwealth parliament

1720.84.text:
has enacted many laws pursuant to section
5126 specifically applicable to Aboriginal

1730.38.text:
and Torres Strait Islander peoples in areas
of cultural heritage, corporations and native

1737.51.text:
title.
However, the amended section 5126, following

1745.40.text:
the 1967 referendum, also presented us with
an unintended consequence, or intended according

1755.69.text:
to who you talk to, and that was that the
power as expressed did not contain any limitations

1765.21.text:
or any qualification by which to prevent its
adverse application against a people of any

1772.88.text:
race.
The panel was persuaded by many submissions

1778.51.text:
made to it that there was now a very reasonably
established legal basis as a consequence of

1787.48.text:
High Court jurisprudence that there is nothing
in section 5126 to prevent its adverse application

1796.18.text:
against a people of any race.
These are submissions referred notably to

1803.45.text:
cases like, well such as Kartinyeri and the
Commonwealth, that the power maybe used to

1812.32.text:
discriminate against or for the benefit of
the people of any race.

1819.80.text:
Rather than amending the race power, the submissions
and the panel lean toward outright deletion

1833.85.text:
but replacement with an alternative head of
power, for two reasons, the first being the

1842.36.text:
original intent of the race power, and the
second being the risk of losing a Commonwealth

1850.32.text:
legislative competence for making laws for
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.

1858.40.text:
On the first reason, original intent, there
was overwhelming concern for the unequivocally

1865.11.text:
racist sentiment that is attached to the history
of section 5126, of which the constitutional

1873.92.text:
convention debates of the 1890s make very
clear and continue to inculcate the section.

1886.71.text:
Some examples of that debate, which for those
who don't know, can be used to interpret provisions

1896.65.text:
of the constitution today.
Australia's first chief justice, Samuel Griffith,

1903.51.text:
first proposed the clause for a grant of an
exclusive legislative power to the Commonwealth

1909.42.text:
with respect to the affairs of people of any
race to whom it is deemed necessary to make

1915.68.text:
special laws and that did not extend to authorise
legislation with respect to the Aboriginal

1923.91.text:
natives in Australia.
In 1898 Edmond Barton, Australia's first Prime

1932.63.text:
Minister and a founding justice of the High
Court, commented that the race power was necessary

1940.44.text:
so that the moment the Commonwealth obtains
any legislative power at all it should have

1947.49.text:
the power to regulate the affairs of the people
of coloured or inferior races who are in the

1955.13.text:
Commonwealth.
And in arguing against such a Commonwealth

1960.99.text:
head of power, the future premier of Western
Australia, Sir John Forrest, contended, we

1968.77.text:
have made a law in Western Australia that
no Asiatic or African alien can get a miners

1976.32.text:
right or do any gold mining.
Does the convention wish to take away from

1982.49.text:
us or at any rate not to give us the power
to continue to legislate in that direction?

1991.28.text:
We also provide that no Asiatic or African
alien shall go on our gold fields.

1997.40.text:
These are local matters which I think should
not be taken from the control of the state

2003.29.text:
parliament.
Forrest also observed that it is of no use

2009.27.text:
for us to shut our eyes to the fact that there
is a great feeling all over Australia against

2015.70.text:
the introduction of coloured persons.
It goes without saying that we do not like

2021.33.text:
to talk about it but still it is so.
The Expert Panel in its research found that

2028.60.text:
the tenor of the convention debates revealed
a very clear intent for laws applying discriminatory

2036.07.text:
controls to coloured races and informed very
much the case for the deletion of the section

2044.23.text:
in its entirety.
And might I say that's with the exception

2048.91.text:
of contributions from Dr John Quick, Charles
Kingston and Josiah Simon, who the panel felt

2057.66.text:
was radically liberal for the time and expressed
the view that if coloured people were to be

2064.31.text:
admitted to Australia they should be admitted
as citizens and enjoy all the rights and privileges

2070.27.text:
of Australian citizenship.
So the current Chief Justice of the High Court

2075.06.text:
has written, or wrote, extra curially, a very
powerful and persuasive book chapter which

2085.05.text:
the Expert Panel looked at very closely, which
argued that if you're going to avoid interpreting

2092.36.text:
the race power with its, I suppose, racist
intent, you have to delete it entirely.

2103.19.text:
Secondly the Expert Panel identified other
risks that are involved in simply deleting

2110.46.text:
section 5126 outright without replacing it.
For example would Aboriginal and Torres Strait

2117.73.text:
Islander corporations be able to be incorporated
under legislation enacted under the corporations

2124.65.text:
power in section 5120 of the constitution?
Another example is the provision of benefits.

2133.63.text:
Some benefits such as the Aboriginal study
assistance scheme may continue to be supported

2139.13.text:
under the social security power but this power
may not support all the measures designed

2144.77.text:
to address Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander
disadvantage.

2149.73.text:
So the risk of a Commonwealth loss of legislative
competence in the absence of a conferral of

2157.37.text:
a new head of power persuaded the Expert Panel
to recommend the deletion of the race power

2164.32.text:
and to make a third recommendation for the
insertion of a new head of power, which we

2170.00.text:
titled section 51a.
Section 51a has, in effect, two parts.

2178.70.text:
It has one, a statement of recognition as
the introductory words to the head of power,

2186.87.text:
and it also has the new head of power replacing
5126.

2192.26.text:
So this recommendation is an important one,
I think it's a pretty neat one.

2201.54.text:
But it's important because there is a popular
belief in the community that recognition in

2206.97.text:
a preamble is what this project is about,
and that is not accurate.

2215.38.text:
Why will there be no recognition in a preamble?
We know that the Australian constitution does

2221.61.text:
not contain a preamble, although there is
a preamble to the imperial Commonwealth of

2227.27.text:
Australia Constitution Act 1900 by which the
parliament at Westminster enacted the Constitution

2234.61.text:
in 1900.
We know that the first eight clauses of the

2238.50.text:
Act referred to as the covering clauses contain
mainly introductory, explanatory and consequential

2248.51.text:
provisions.
It's the ninth clause of the Act that contains

2252.16.text:
the Australian Constitution.
The Expert Panel decided against placing a

2258.03.text:
statement of recognition in the preamble to
the Imperial Act because it's the orthodox

2263.12.text:
view that section 128 of the Constitution
can not be used to amend the preamble to the

2270.93.text:
Commonwealth of Australian Constitution Act.
In addition the Panel was persuaded by submissions

2277.47.text:
including a very comprehensive submission
on this point by Professor Anne Twomey of

2283.13.text:
the challenges or problems associated with
placing a preamble at the beginning of the

2289.48.text:
Australian Constitution contained in the ninth
clause.

2295.95.text:
As I indicated before this is an important
finding of the Expert Panel because the idea

2301.76.text:
of a recognition statement in a preamble to
the Constitution is probably where the current

2307.45.text:
project sits in terms of the political and
popular imagination.

2313.08.text:
It's perhaps a hangover from the 1999 referendum.
Yet during our consultations around Australia

2321.13.text:
we found that those Australians who turned
their mind to this question, they had thought

2327.00.text:
about the experience of 1999 and were eager
to avoid the travails associated with that

2337.60.text:
preamble.
Of course one such challenge would be that

2345.24.text:
many, many groups would also want to be included
and rightly so.

2351.28.text:
After all we're a nation that has had waves
and waves of immigration, and there are many

2358.92.text:
groups that make up who we are as Australians.
However we felt that our terms of reference

2365.83.text:
confined us to consider options for Indigenous
recognition and therefore keen to avoid the

2372.26.text:
experience of 1999 by opening that up.
Another consideration here is the issue of

2378.83.text:
the no legal effect clause; this issue arose
during the consultation because of the state

2385.38.text:
parliaments' trend toward recognition.
Victoria, Queensland, NSW and South Australia,

2392.77.text:
they've all moved to amend their preambles
to recognise Aboriginal and Torres Strait

2398.70.text:
Islander peoples.
By way of example, Queensland's preamble reads:

2404.29.text:
The Aboriginal peoples and the Torres Strait
Islander peoples, the first Australians whose

2409.69.text:
lands, winds and waters we all now share,
and pay tribute to their unique values and

2416.24.text:
ancient and enduring cultures which deepen
and enrich the life of our community.

2424.86.text:
And then beneath that, section 3a of the Act
provides in acknowledging Aboriginal and Torres

2433.02.text:
Strait Islander peoples, the Parliament does
not create any persons any legal right or

2439.77.text:
give rise to any civil cause of action or
affect the interpretation of the Queensland

2445.32.text:
Constitution or any other law in force in
Queensland.

2452.20.text:
Similarly NSW has a very powerful preamble,
a preambular recognition.

2459.72.text:
It reads: Parliament on behalf of the people
of NSW acknowledges and honours the Aboriginal

2466.14.text:
people as the state's first peoples and nations.
Parliament on behalf of the NSW peoples recognises

2474.60.text:
Aboriginal people as the traditional custodians
and occupants of the land in NSW.

2479.83.text:
They have a spiritual, social, cultural and
economic relationship with their traditional

2488.52.text:
lands and waters and have made and continue
to make a unique and lasting contribution

2493.99.text:
to the identity of the state.
And nothing in this section creates any legal

2499.47.text:
right or liability or gives rise to or affects
any civil cause of action or right of review

2509.68.text:
or right to review an administrative action
or affects the interpretation of any act or

2515.12.text:
law in force in NSW.
The value of a symbolic gesture of reconciliation

2523.50.text:
is significant and a preamble can act as a
powerful instrument of change, so I do not

2529.10.text:
want to undervalue the achievement of state
parliaments in securing recognition, plus

2536.04.text:
no legal effect clause.
As an exercise in the expression of collective

2541.25.text:
beliefs a preamble can represent what, or
can represent the transformative potential

2548.01.text:
of words because of what we just explored
at the outset with Toni Morrison and the implied

2554.79.text:
reader.
But what was striking from our conversations

2559.23.text:
as we travelled around Australia and particularly
from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander

2565.39.text:
communities, was that a preamble was almost
universally not desired, especially if it

2573.88.text:
contained a no legal effect clause, which
was frequently disparaged by Indigenous and

2582.13.text:
non-indigenous peoples as tokenistic.
As one Australian put it to us, in a community

2591.09.text:
consultation, what is the use of doing it,
if you're going to say that it has no effect.

2599.35.text:
In addition I suppose the disingenuous nature
of the state parliaments' recognition is that

2606.13.text:
their constitutions are an ordinary act of
parliament, so anything inconsistent with

2612.43.text:
the recognition clause could simply be ameliorated
by passing a subsequent piece of legislation.

2623.52.text:
So on the basis of this sentiment from the
Australian people we did write a statement

2629.13.text:
of recognition but we placed it in the introductory
section to a new head of power.

2638.53.text:
The statement of recognition reads:
Recognising that the continent and its islands

2644.92.text:
now known as Australia were first occupied
by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples,

2651.43.text:
acknowledging the continuing relationship
of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples,

2657.69.text:
their traditional land and waters.
Respecting the continuing cultures, languages

2664.10.text:
and heritage of Aboriginal and Torres Strait
Islander peoples and then acknowledging the

2669.69.text:
need to secure the advancement of Aboriginal
and Torres Strait Islander peoples.

2676.73.text:
Then the power goes onto say, the parliament
shall have made laws, should have power to

2681.10.text:
make laws with respect to Aboriginal and Torres
Strait Islander peoples.

2691.81.text:
Now the last two recommendations are, our
fourth recommendation was for a prohibition

2697.15.text:
of racial discrimination to be known as section
116a.

2703.02.text:
It reads that: The Commonwealth, a state or
a territory shall not discriminate on the

2707.99.text:
grounds of race, colour or ethnic or national
origin.

2713.23.text:
Sub-section 2 reads: Sub-section 1 does not
preclude the making of laws or measures for

2718.70.text:
the purpose of overcoming disadvantage, ameliorating
the effects of past discrimination or protecting

2725.02.text:
the cultures, languages or heritage of any
group.

2728.52.text:
I'll return to this in the moment when I conclude.
And finally recommendation 5 was that a new

2736.77.text:
section 127a be inserted into the Australian
Constitution.

2743.19.text:
It reads: Sub-section 1, the national language
of the Commonwealth of Australia is English,

2752.71.text:
and sub-section 2, the Aboriginal and Torres
Strait Islander languages are the original

2758.39.text:
Australian language,s a part of our national
heritage.

2762.06.text:
So I want to conclude now by returning to
recommendation 4, the racial non-discrimination

2769.62.text:
clause.
Because one of the responses to the recommendations

2775.21.text:
of the Expert Panel was that we had over-reached
our mandate, and that a racial non-discrimination

2783.77.text:
provision was not relevant to the notion of
recognition.

2790.22.text:
A non-discrimination clause was not relevant
to recognition.

2795.62.text:
The word 'recognition' that was used in the
terms of reference for the expert panel was

2801.16.text:
something that was adopted by the federal
government and not the expert panel.

2808.14.text:
It was no doubt partly something that was,
as I said before, a hangover from the 1999

2814.26.text:
referendum, and in part mirrors the language
or sentiment of the multi-party election platforms

2822.65.text:
leading into the 2010 federal election.
And it certainly echoed the fashion in state

2829.79.text:
parliaments of the recognition of Aboriginal
and Torres Strait Islander, well of Aboriginal

2837.22.text:
and Torres Strait Islander peoples and their
constitutions, with the no legal effect clause.

2844.19.text:
Regardless, recognition is the language that
has been used and the language that we need

2848.74.text:
to work with.
One of the challenges of the word 'recognition'

2853.03.text:
is that unlike the word 'reform' for example,
it requires us to engage in not so technical

2860.02.text:
arguments.
Even though that is what the project is about,

2863.84.text:
it requires us to engage with primarily emotion
and sentiment.

2870.85.text:
What is it to recognise someone?
What is it to recognise a peoples?

2879.60.text:
And that is why I started my lecture with
the story of Cherbourg, because at the very

2887.94.text:
same time that Aboriginal people, particularly
the Waka Waka group, were being herded into

2895.19.text:
the Barambah mission, into the Cherbourg reserve,
at the very same time while Australia was

2901.70.text:
celebrating its new constitution, its new
federation, its new sense of nationhood.

2909.80.text:
The view of the panel is that a racial non-discrimination
clause is an integral part of any package

2918.52.text:
to recognise Aboriginal and Torres Strait
Islander peoples.

2924.38.text:
Legally Australia is already committed to
the principle of racial non-discrimination

2928.29.text:
as reflected in the Racial Discrimination
Act, the Commonwealth Act.

2933.94.text:
It is accepted in legislation and policy in
all Australian jurisdictions.

2940.94.text:
Constitutional lawyers submitted to the panel
that discrimination is quite a familiar concept

2945.16.text:
for the courts and so applying it in a new
context isn't such a great stretch.

2953.72.text:
And that it is also contained in many constitutions
around the world, and there's a wealth of

2961.40.text:
overseas jurisprudence and international law
on this issue on which the courts can draw.

2969.71.text:
It was noted that this clause, section 116a,
will primarily place the additional burden

2979.32.text:
on the Commonwealth parliament, and that was
quite a popular idea in the community.

2987.97.text:
Of course that alone does not neutralise Australian
exceptionalism when it comes to rights, given

2996.28.text:
that the Australian exceptionalism on rights
is regarded today as being a virtue, and indeed

3004.28.text:
an argument in its own right.
But the fact is that the submissions to the

3010.53.text:
panel overwhelmingly supported a racial non-discrimination
provision, and it was our job to reflect what

3018.99.text:
the community was thinking and telling us.
I think my fellow expert panel member and

3028.02.text:
Cape York leader Noel Pearson argued it best
when he said, partly in response to this critique,

3035.43.text:
that non-discrimination is not at all related
to the recognition project.

3040.93.text:
He said that the elimination of racial discrimination
is inherently related to Indigenous recognition,

3049.19.text:
because Indigenous people in Australia more
than any other group suffered more racial,

3055.79.text:
suffer much racial discrimination than in
the past.

3059.78.text:
So extreme was the discrimination against
Indigenous people, it even, it initially even

3065.14.text:
denied that we existed.
Hence Indigenous Australians were not recognised.

3072.23.text:
Then, Indigenous people were explicitly excluded
in our Constitution, and still today we are

3080.45.text:
subject to racially targeted laws, with no
requirement that such laws be beneficial,

3087.98.text:
and no prohibition against adverse discrimination.
Even with the 1967 referendum, Aboriginal

3099.10.text:
and Torres Strait Islander people are not
the implied reader of the constitution.

3106.01.text:
You cannot separate this recognition project
and the recommendations of the expert panel

3112.58.text:
from the history of this country.
The stories that Australians told us and the

3119.16.text:
stories that Australians still have to tell.
We had very conservative members of our panel

3126.09.text:
who were not at all sympathetic to anything
other than recognition in a preamble.

3134.19.text:
They were not at all sympathetic to a racial
non-discrimination clause, and they were moved

3141.92.text:
by the end of the year by visiting places
like Cherbourg, moved by the stories of Aboriginal

3150.97.text:
elders, to support a non-discrimination provision
in the Constitution.

3160.60.text:
The consensus in the Expert Panel report and
the recommendations is no mean feat.

3167.71.text:
In itself it was a journey towards reconciliation
for those involved, and the recommendations

3175.67.text:
were not made lightly.
In fact we rehearsed endlessly what the automated

3181.54.text:
response will be from those who will predictably
and publicly oppose, in particular this notion

3190.10.text:
of rights, this one right, this section 116a,
this non-discrimination clause, and that response

3199.82.text:
played out on queue.
We got told it was a back door bill of rights,

3205.66.text:
or a one clause bill of rights, and that will
continue to play out.

3211.52.text:
And that is not to diminish at all the genuine
and legitimate concerns that some have about

3219.21.text:
inserting rights into the Constitution, whether
it's judicial activism or the impact of that

3226.17.text:
right upon other heads of power.
But what we can say is that the report is

3233.36.text:
filled with the voices of ordinary Australians
making a contribution and having a go at something

3238.92.text:
that our leaders have so far failed to do,
and that is engaging with the very difficult

3244.56.text:
conversations of race and our racist history.
Our news polling showed that at the end of

3253.29.text:
the process with our recommendations, 80%
of Australians that we polled supported a

3260.69.text:
non-discrimination clause.
None of the other recommendations that I read

3266.00.text:
out, of the five, got anywhere close to what
the non-discrimination clause got in terms

3272.06.text:
of polling.
We were told by Newspoll, there's enough support

3275.97.text:
there for it to fall away with no campaign
and you still get it across the line.

3281.56.text:
I mean that was two years ago but the point
I am trying to make, is that without the politicising,

3288.19.text:
without the anti-bill of rights, a team coming
into play, I think that it was intuitive,

3299.63.text:
probably to most Australians the notion that
we should be equal before the law and that

3307.02.text:
no one should be discriminated against on
the basis of their race.

3312.33.text:
And in the non-discrimination clause containing
a special measures provision which I read

3317.45.text:
out, Australians also understood in our consultations,
they also intuitively got the notion that

3326.38.text:
in some cases, there are people in our community
who do need additional assistance for a period

3333.23.text:
of time to get to the same level of capability
as other Australians in our community.

3340.87.text:
And this we felt is because it is embedded
in our commitment to universal health care,

3347.32.text:
the welfare system, and affordable state housing.
But not everyone can visit places like Cherbourg

3359.32.text:
and be moved by that history and not everyone
is interested in that, and so it was that

3364.86.text:
we found out, as a panel, that there was a
thirst out there in the Australian community

3372.07.text:
for more knowledge, for more learning about
Aboriginal history, more knowledge about the

3380.29.text:
stories of reserves like Cherbourg and the
protection era.

3384.98.text:
There was a hesitance and a caution of behalf
of many who felt that they did not know enough

3389.52.text:
about Aboriginal people and Aboriginal history
to voice an opinion or become involved.

3396.47.text:
They were not silent because they were racist
or disengaged; they earnestly said that they

3402.55.text:
did not know how to enter the discussion.
It is not that people wanted to feel guilty

3410.08.text:
or to apologise, but it's that they wanted
to understand where Aboriginal people were

3416.49.text:
coming from
And we captured that in the final report,

3421.60.text:
a palpable universal sentiment in all the
communities that we went in black and white

3428.53.text:
Australia, that they wanted, that they needed
to know more about Australian history.

3434.83.text:
Not just military feats and defeats, but all
facets of Australian history including our

3442.16.text:
successive waves of successful migration as
well as the White Australia policy.

3449.91.text:
And that was the interesting thing that many
places we went people did not know about the

3456.88.text:
White Australia policy.
They did not know about the frontier, or the

3464.63.text:
stolen wages, and most did not know that Australia
had a protection era.

3474.51.text:
Which is a great pity because it does provide
an explanation for many things, the lack of

3482.86.text:
intergenerational wealth for example, that
people couldn't keep their wages, that people

3488.36.text:
couldn't keep a budget, that people couldn't
pass down property, that people couldn't pass

3494.20.text:
down their money to their families and, for
many, an explanation for intergenerational

3504.44.text:
trauma.
Not an excuse for behaviour today but an explanation.

3512.98.text:
And there were many Australians who felt strongly
that they grew up on this land, they were

3517.54.text:
born to this country and that Aboriginal culture
and Aboriginal history was something that

3524.40.text:
was the common inheritance of all Australians.
And many Aboriginal people agreed with that.

3533.95.text:
They want Australians to learn more about
Aboriginal culture and learn some of the languages,

3541.51.text:
and of course there were some Aboriginal people
that did not support that notion at all.

3547.64.text:
But all in all, people were open and frank
and generous and public in their opinions

3554.80.text:
about racism in Australia and the place of
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples

3561.47.text:
in the story of this country.
For Australians to learn more about our history,

3570.14.text:
to know that history, Aboriginal history,
is not to diminish who we are or to adopt

3578.90.text:
that terrible phrase, a black arm band view
of history.

3583.98.text:
The nature of our democracy is that in the
culture wars the pendulum swings back and

3590.87.text:
forth each decade as a new government dictates
the way that history will be viewed, and then

3597.19.text:
it swings back.
To the victor goes the spoils, that is the

3601.01.text:
nature of our democracy.
But, I do urge you, if you have not already

3610.55.text:
to do two things, one, to read the report
of the expert panel and secondly to visit

3620.46.text:
Cherbourg and the ration shed.
It is truly one of the most beautiful but

3626.95.text:
yet difficult monuments to Australian history.
Here you have a community that has reclaimed

3635.01.text:
its history and made the ration shed the site
of so much humiliation and anger and pain

3643.20.text:
the centrepiece of its town.
If this mob in Cherbourg can do it with grace

3651.11.text:
and with humour and with gravitas, why can't
we do it as Australians?

3657.60.text:
And that is the challenge that lies ahead
for us as we apparently move in to this next

3664.26.text:
phase, which is moving towards a referendum
in the next parliamentary term.

3671.92.text:
Wouldn't it be great if this great Australian
ritual of section 128, which has only been

3680.41.text:
successfully performed eight out of forty-four
times, and spectacularly performed in 1967.

3690.41.text:
Wouldn't it be great if this Australian ritual
was once again performed successfully as a

3698.14.text:
celebration of Australia's Aboriginal and
Torres Strait Islander peoples?
